eet%20a%20chosen%20SLA.%20Our%20SLA%20was%201%20second,%20so%20once%20per%20second%20we%20wrote%20updated%20windows%20to%20Redis.%20Spark%20operated%20slightly%20differently%20due%20to%20great%20differences%20in%20its%20design.%20There%E2%80%99s%20more%20details%20on%20that%20in%20the%20Spark%20section.%20Along%20with%20the%20data,%20we%20record%20the%20time%20at%20which%20each%20window%20in%20Redis%20was%20last%20updated.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EAfter%20each%20run,%20a%20utility%20reads%20windows%20from%20Redis%20and%20compares%20the%20windows%E2%80%99%20times%20to%20their%20%3Ci%3Elast_updated_at%3C/i%3E%20times,%20yielding%20a%20latency%20data%20point.%20Because%20the%20last%20event%20for%20a%20window%20cannot%20have%20been%20emitted%20after%20the%20window%20closed%20but%20will%20be%20very%20shortly%20before,%20the%20difference%20between%20a%20window%E2%80%99s%20time%20and%20its%20last_updated_at%20time%20minus%20its%20duration%20represents%20the%20time%20it%20took%20for%20the%20final%20tuple%20in%20a%20window%20to%20go%20from%20Kafka%20to%20Redis%20through%20the%20application.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3E%3Ci%3Ewindow.final_event_latency%20=%20(window.last_updated_at%20%E2%80%93%20window.timestamp)%20%E2%80%93%20window.duration%3C/i%3E%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThis%20is%20a%20bit%20rough,%20but%20this%20benchmark%20was%20not%20purposed%20to%20get%20fine-grained%20numbers%20on%20these%20engines,%20but%20to%20provide%20a%20more%20high-level%20view%20of%20their%20behavior.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EBenchmark%20setup%3C/p%3E%3Cul%3E%3Cli%3E10%20second%20windows%3C/li%3E%3Cli%3E1%20second%20SLA%3C/li%3E%3Cli%3E100%20campaigns%3C/li%3E%3Cli%3E10%20ads%20per%20campaign%3C/li%3E%3Cli%3E5%20Kafka%20nodes%20with%205%20partitions%3C/li%3E%3Cli%3E1%20Redis%20node%3C/li%3E%3Cli%3E10%20worker%20nodes%20(not%20including%20coordination%20nodes%20like%20Storm%E2%80%99s%20Nimbus)%3C/li%3E%3Cli%3E5-10%20Kafka%20producer%20nodes%3C/li%3E%3Cli%3E3%20ZooKeeper%20nodes%3C/li%3E%3C/ul%3E%3Cp%3ESince%20the%20Redis%20node%20in%20our%20architecture%20only%20performs%20in-memory%20lookups%20using%20a%20well-optimized%20hashing%20scheme,%20it%20did%20not%20become%20a%20bottleneck.%20The%20nodes%20are%20homogeneously%20configured,%20each%20with%20two%20Intel%20E5530%20processors%20running%20at%202.4GHz,%20with%20a%20total%20of%2016%20cores%20(8%20physical,%2016%20hyperthreading)%20per%20node.%20Each%20node%20has%2024GiB%20of%20memory,%20and%20the%20machines%20are%20all%20located%20within%20the%20same%20rack,%20connected%20through%20a%20gigabit%20Ethernet%20switch.%20The%20cluster%20has%20a%20total%20of%2040%20nodes%20available.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EWe%20ran%20multiple%20instances%20of%20the%20Kafka%20producers%20to%20create%20the%20required%20load%20since%20individual%20producers%20begin%20to%20fall%20behind%20at%20around%2017,000%20events%20per%20second.%20In%20total,%20we%20use%20anywhere%20between%2020%20to%2025%20nodes%20in%20this%20benchmark.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20use%20of%2010%20workers%20for%20a%20topology%20is%20near%20the%20average%20number%20we%20see%20being%20used%20by%20topologies%20internal%20to%20Yahoo.%20Of%20course,%20our%20Storm%20clusters%20are%20larger%20in%20size,%20but%20they%20are%20multi-tenant%20and%20run%20many%20topologies.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3ETo%20begin%20the%20benchmarks%20Kafka%20is%20cleared,%20Redis%20is%20populated%20with%20initial%20data%20(%3Ci%3Ead_id%3C/i%3E%20to%20%3Ci%3Ecampaign_id%3C/i%3E%20mapping),%20the%20streaming%20job%20is%20started,%20and%20then%20after%20a%20bit%20of%20time%20to%20let%20the%20job%20finish%20launching,%20the%20producers%20are%20started%20with%20instructions%20to%20produce%20events%20at%20a%20particular%20rate,%20giving%20the%20desired%20aggregate%20throughput.%20The%20system%20was%20left%20to%20run%20for%2030%20minutes%20before%20the%20producers%20were%20shut%20down.%20A%20few%20seconds%20were%20allowed%20for%20all%20events%20to%20be%20processed%20before%20the%20streaming%20job%20itself%20was%20stopped.%20The%20benchmark%20utility%20was%20then%20run%20to%20generate%20a%20file%20containing%20a%20list%20of%20%3Ci%3Ewindow.last_updated_at%20%E2%80%93%20window.timestamp%3C/i%3E%20numbers.%20These%20files%20were%20saved%20for%20each%20throughput%20we%20tested%20and%20then%20were%20used%20to%20generate%20the%20charts%20in%20this%20document.%3C/p%3E%3Ch2%3E%3Cb%3EFlink%3C/b%3E%3C/h2%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20benchmark%20for%20Flink%20was%20implemented%20in%20Java%20by%20using%20Flink%E2%80%99s%20DataStream%20API.%20%C2%A0The%20Flink%20DataStream%20API%20has%20many%20similarities%20to%20Storm%E2%80%99s%20streaming%20API.%20%C2%A0For%20both%20Flink%20and%20Storm,%20the%20dataflow%20can%20be%20represented%20as%20a%20directed%20graph.%20Each%20vertex%20is%20a%20user%20defined%20operator%20and%20each%20directed%20edge%20represents%20a%20flow%20of%20data.%20%C2%A0Storm%E2%80%99s%20API%20uses%20spouts%20and%20bolts%20as%20its%20operators%20while%20Flink%20uses%20map,%20flatMap,%20as%20well%20as%20many%20pre-built%20operators%20such%20as%20filter,%20project,%20and%20reduce.%20Flink%20uses%20a%20mechanism%20called%20checkpointing%20to%20guarantee%20processing.%20Unless%20checkpointing%20is%20used%20in%20the%20Flink%20job,%20Flink%20offers%20at%20most%20once%20processing%20similar%20to%20Storm%20with%20acking%20turned%20on.%20%C2%A0For%20the%20Flink%20benchmark%20we%20did%20not%20use%20checkpointing.%20%C2%A0Notable%20configs%20we%20used%20in%20Flink%20is%20listed%20below:%3C/p%3E%3Cul%3E%3Cli%3Etaskmanager.heap.mb:%2015360%3C/li%3E%3Cli%3Etaskmanager.numberOfTaskSlots:%2016%3C/li%3E%3C/ul%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20Flink%20version%20of%20the%20benchmark%20uses%20the%20FlinkKafkaConsumer%20to%20read%20data%20in%20from%20Kafka.%20%C2%A0The%20data%20read%20in%20from%20Kafka%E2%80%94which%20is%20in%20a%20JSON%20formatted%20string%E2%80%94%20is%20then%20deserialized%20and%20parsed%20by%20a%20custom%20defined%20flatMap%20operator.%20Once%20deserialized,%20the%20data%20is%20filtered%20via%20a%20custom%20defined%20filter%20operator.%20Afterwards,%20the%20filtered%20data%20is%20projected%20by%20using%20the%20project%20operator.%20From%20there,%20the%20data%20is%20joined%20with%20data%20in%20Redis%20by%20a%20custom%20defined%20flapMap%20function.%20Lastly,%20the%20final%20results%20are%20calculated%20from%20the%20data%20and%20written%20to%20redis.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20rate%20at%20which%20Kafka%20emitted%20data%20events%20into%20the%20Flink%20benchmark%20is%20varied%20from%2050,000%20events/sec%20to%20170,000%20events/sec.%20For%20each%20Kafka%20emit%20rate,%20the%20percentile%20latency%20for%20a%20tuple%20to%20be%20completely%20processed%20in%20the%20Flink%20benchmark%20is%20illustrated%20in%20the%20graph%20below.%3C/p%3E%3Cfigure%20class=%22tmblr-full%22%20data-orig-height=%22365%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/ad625d5307b79ab4fab204c7fde1b733/tumblr_inline_nzet5oeYfc1spdvr2_540.png%22%3E%3Cimg%20alt=%22%22%20src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/a32a2d127b8a07ec02b12fd18a77ee41/tumblr_inline_pecnpmUhEO1t17fny_540.png%22%20data-orig-height=%22365%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/ad625d5307b79ab4fab204c7fde1b733/tumblr_inline_nzet5oeYfc1spdvr2_540.png%22/%3E%3C/figure%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20percentile%20latency%20for%20all%20Kafka%20emit%20rates%20are%20relatively%20the%20same.%20The%20percentile%20latency%20rises%20linearly%20until%20around%20the%2099th%20percentile,%20where%20the%20latency%20appears%20to%20increase%20exponentially.%20%C2%A0%3C/p%3E%3Ch2%3E%3Cb%3ESpark%3C/b%3E%3C/h2%3E%3Cp%3EFor%20the%20Spark%20benchmark,%20the%20code%20was%20written%20in%20Scala.%20Since%20the%20micro-batching%20methodology%20of%20Spark%20is%20different%20than%20the%20pure%20streaming%20nature%20of%20Storm,%20we%20needed%20to%20rethink%20parts%20of%20the%20benchmark.%20Storm%20and%20Flink%20benchmarks%20would%20update%20the%20Redis%20database%20once%20a%20second%20to%20try%20and%20meet%20our%20SLA,%20keeping%20the%20intermediate%20update%20values%20in%20a%20local%20cache.%20As%20a%20result,%20the%20batch%20duration%20in%20the%20Spark%20streaming%20version%20was%20set%20to%201%20second,%20at%20least%20for%20smaller%20amounts%20of%20traffic.%20We%20had%20to%20increase%20the%20batch%20duration%20for%20larger%20throughputs.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20benchmark%20is%20written%20in%20a%20typical%20Spark%20style%20using%20DStreams.%20DStreams%20are%20the%20streaming%20equivalent%20of%20regular%20RDDs,%20and%20create%20a%20separate%20RDD%20for%20every%20micro%20batch.%20Note%20that%20in%20the%20subsequent%20discussion,%20we%20use%20the%20term%20%E2%80%9CRDD%E2%80%9D%20instead%20of%20%E2%80%9CDStream%E2%80%9D%20to%20refer%20to%20the%20RDD%20representation%20of%20the%20DStream%20in%20the%20currently%20active%20microbatch.%20Processing%20begins%20with%20the%20direct%20Kafka%20consumer%20included%20with%20Spark%201.5.%20Since%20the%20Kafka%20input%20data%20in%20our%20benchmark%20is%20stored%20in%205%20partitions,%20this%20Kafka%20consumer%20creates%20a%20DStream%20with%205%20partitions%20as%20well.%20After%20that,%20a%20number%20of%20transformations%20are%20applied%20on%20the%20DStreams,%20including%20maps%20and%20filters.%20The%20transformation%20involving%20joining%20data%20with%20Redis%20is%20a%20special%20case.%20Since%20we%20do%20not%20want%20to%20create%20a%20separate%20connection%20to%20Redis%20for%20each%20record,%20we%20use%20a%20mapPartitions%20operation%20that%20can%20give%20control%20of%20a%20whole%20RDD%20partition%20to%20our%20code.%20%C2%A0This%20way,%20we%20create%20one%20connection%20to%20Redis%20and%20use%20this%20single%20connection%20to%20query%20information%20from%20Redis%20for%20all%20the%20events%20in%20that%20RDD%20partition.%20The%20same%20approach%20is%20used%20later%20when%20we%20update%20the%20final%20results%20in%20Redis.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EIt%20should%20be%20noted%20that%20our%20writes%20to%20Redis%20were%20implemented%20as%20a%20side-effect%20of%20the%20execution%20of%20the%20RDD%20transformation%20in%20order%20to%20keep%20the%20benchmark%20simple,%20so%20this%20would%20not%20be%20compatible%20with%20exactly-once%20semantics.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EWe%20found%20that%20with%20high%20enough%20throughput,%20Spark%20was%20not%20able%20to%20keep%20up.%20%C2%A0At%20100,000%20messages%20per%20second%20the%20latency%20greatly%20increased.%20We%20considered%20adjustments%20along%20two%20control%20dimensions%20to%20help%20Spark%20cope%20with%20increasing%20throughput.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20first%20is%20the%20microbatch%20duration.%20This%20is%20a%20control%20dimension%20that%20is%20not%20present%20in%20a%20pure%20streaming%20system%20like%20Storm.%20Increasing%20the%20duration%20increases%20latency%20while%20reducing%20overhead%20and%20therefore%20increasing%20maximum%20throughput.%20The%20challenge%20is%20that%20the%20choice%20of%20the%20optimal%20batch%20duration%20that%20minimizes%20latency%20while%20allowing%20spark%20to%20handle%20the%20throughput%20is%20a%20time%20consuming%20process.%20Essentially,%20we%20have%20to%20set%20a%20batch%20duration,%20run%20the%20benchmark%20for%2030%20minutes,%20check%20the%20results%20and%20decrease/increase%20the%20duration.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20second%20dimension%20is%20parallelism.%20However,%20increasing%20parallelism%20is%20simpler%20said%20than%20done%20in%20the%20case%20of%20Spark.%20For%20a%20true%20streaming%20system%20like%20Storm,%20one%20bolt%20instance%20can%20send%20its%20results%20to%20any%20number%20of%20subsequent%20bolt%20instances%20by%20using%20a%20random%20shuffle.%20To%20scale,%20one%20can%20increase%20the%20parallelism%20of%20the%20second%20bolt.%20In%20the%20case%20of%20a%20micro%20batch%20system%20like%20Spark,%20we%20need%20to%20perform%20a%20reshuffle%20operation%20similar%20to%20how%20intermediate%20data%20in%20a%20Hadoop%20MapReduce%20program%20are%20shuffled%20and%20merged%20across%20the%20cluster.%20But%20the%20reshuffling%20itself%20introduces%20considerable%20overhead.%20Initially,%20we%20thought%20our%20operations%20were%20CPU-bound,%20and%20so%20the%20benefits%20of%20reshuffling%20to%20a%20higher%20number%20of%20partitions%20would%20outweigh%20the%20cost%20of%20reshuffling.%20%C2%A0Instead,%20we%20found%20the%20bottleneck%20to%20be%20scheduling,%20and%20so%20reshuffling%20only%20added%20overhead.%20We%20suspect%20that%20at%20higher%20throughput%20rates%20or%20with%20operations%20that%20are%20CPU-bound,%20the%20reverse%20would%20be%20true.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20final%20results%20are%20interesting.%20There%20are%20essentially%20three%20behaviors%20for%20a%20Spark%20workload%20depending%20on%20the%20window%20duration.%20First,%20if%20the%20batch%20duration%20is%20set%20sufficiently%20large,%20the%20majority%20of%20the%20events%20will%20be%20handled%20within%20the%20current%20micro%20batch.%20The%20following%20figure%20shows%20the%20resulting%20percentile%20processing%20graph%20for%20this%20case%20(100K%20events,%2010%20seconds%20batch%20duration).%3C/p%3E%3Cfigure%20class=%22tmblr-full%22%20data-orig-height=%22370%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/9f1f17e7ea760b5a1fc65f135b426a46/tumblr_inline_nzet5rxBg81spdvr2_540.png%22%3E%3Cimg%20alt=%22%22%20src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/9a8a7ef36080b0c49dbd874dbce82e82/tumblr_inline_pecnpm7Xbp1t17fny_540.png%22%20data-orig-height=%22370%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/9f1f17e7ea760b5a1fc65f135b426a46/tumblr_inline_nzet5rxBg81spdvr2_540.png%22/%3E%3C/figure%3E%3Cp%3EBut%20whenever%2090%%20of%20events%20are%20processed%20in%20the%20first%20batch,%20there%20is%20possibility%20of%20improving%20latency.%20By%20reducing%20the%20batch%20duration%20sufficiently,%20we%20get%20into%20a%20region%20where%20the%20incoming%20events%20are%20processed%20within%203%20or%204%20subsequent%20batches.%20This%20is%20the%20second%20behavior,%20in%20which%20the%20batch%20duration%20puts%20the%20system%20on%20the%20verge%20of%20falling%20behind,%20but%20is%20still%20manageable,%20and%20results%20in%20better%20latency.%20This%20situation%20is%20shown%20in%20the%20following%20figure%20for%20a%20sample%20throughput%20rate%20(100K%20events,%203%20seconds%20batch%20duration).%3C/p%3E%3Cfigure%20class=%22tmblr-full%22%20data-orig-height=%22366%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/f6f8e5d5a0e6d621e820bc0cffba9b2a/tumblr_inline_nzet5qLz2X1spdvr2_540.png%22%3E%3Cimg%20alt=%22%22%20src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/f70a928da49ce4580c85a68e7210929c/tumblr_inline_pecnpma4NJ1t17fny_540.png%22%20data-orig-height=%22366%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/f6f8e5d5a0e6d621e820bc0cffba9b2a/tumblr_inline_nzet5qLz2X1spdvr2_540.png%22/%3E%3C/figure%3E%3Cp%3EFinally,%20the%20third%20behavior%20is%20when%20Spark%20streaming%20falls%20behind.%20In%20this%20case,%20the%20benchmark%20takes%20a%20few%20minutes%20after%20the%20input%20data%20finishes%20to%20process%20all%20of%20the%20events.%20This%20situation%20is%20shown%20in%20the%20following%20figure.%20Under%20this%20undesirable%20operating%20region,%20Spark%20spills%20lots%20of%20data%20onto%20disks,%20and%20in%20extreme%20cases%20we%20could%20end%20up%20running%20out%20of%20disk%20space.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EOne%20final%20note%20is%20that%20we%20tried%20the%20new%20back%20pressure%20feature%20introduced%20in%20Spark%201.5.%20If%20the%20system%20is%20in%20the%20first%20operating%20region,%20enabling%20back%20pressure%20does%20nothing.%20In%20the%20second%20operating%20region,%20enabling%20back%20pressure%20results%20in%20longer%20latencies.%20The%20third%20operating%20region%20is%20where%20back%20pressure%20shows%20the%20most%20negative%20impact.%20%C2%A0It%20changes%20the%20batch%20length,%20but%20Spark%20still%20cannot%20cope%20with%20the%20throughput%20and%20falls%20behind.%20This%20is%20shown%20in%20the%20next%20figures.%20Our%20experiments%20showed%20that%20the%20current%20back%20pressure%20implementation%20did%20not%20help%20our%20benchmark,%20and%20as%20a%20result%20we%20disabled%20it.%3C/p%3E%3Cfigure%20class=%22tmblr-full%22%20data-orig-height=%22369%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/a6bc6c128e64a117f8d068e78b1ded60/tumblr_inline_nzet5r68Um1spdvr2_540.png%22%3E%3Cimg%20alt=%22%22%20src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/6fcbbf78a4b9a7db6d5b1a6c49c4240b/tumblr_inline_pecnpnD96v1t17fny_540.png%22%20data-orig-height=%22369%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/a6bc6c128e64a117f8d068e78b1ded60/tumblr_inline_nzet5r68Um1spdvr2_540.png%22/%3E%3C/figure%3E%3Cfigure%20class=%22tmblr-full%22%20data-orig-height=%22367%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/6884852b7619285bbd93e17efe7e1832/tumblr_inline_nzet5sebGd1spdvr2_540.png%22%3E%3Cimg%20alt=%22%22%20src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/dc67479ae9f954720963d94493d682f9/tumblr_inline_pecnpnymmK1t17fny_540.png%22%20data-orig-height=%22367%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/6884852b7619285bbd93e17efe7e1832/tumblr_inline_nzet5sebGd1spdvr2_540.png%22/%3E%3C/figure%3E%3Cp%3E%3Ci%3E%3Cb%3EPerformance%20without%20back%20pressure%20(top),%20and%20with%20back%20pressure%20enabled%20(bottom).%20The%20latencies%20with%20the%20back%20pressure%20enabled%20are%20worse%20(70%20seconds%20vs%20120%20seconds).%20Note%20that%20both%20of%20these%20results%20are%20unacceptable%20for%20a%20streaming%20system%20as%20both%20fall%20behind%20the%20incoming%20data.%20Batch%20duration%20was%20set%20to%202%20seconds%20for%20each%20run,%20with%20130,000%20throughput.%3C/b%3E%3C/i%3E%3C/p%3E%3Ch2%3E%3Cb%3EStorm%3C/b%3E%3C/h2%3E%3Cp%3EStorm%E2%80%99s%20benchmark%20was%20written%20using%20the%20Java%20API.%20We%20tested%20both%20Apache%20Storm%200.10.0%20release%20and%20a%200.11.0%20snapshot.%20The%20snapshot%E2%80%99s%20commit%20hash%20was%20a8d253a.%20One%20worker%20process%20per%20host%20was%20used,%20and%20each%20worker%20was%20given%2016%20tasks%20to%20run%20in%2016%20executors%20-%20one%20for%20each%20core.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EStorm%200.10.0:%3C/p%3E%3Cfigure%20class=%22tmblr-full%22%20data-orig-height=%22368%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/4bb815ba6ae9e8ca100f753effd78d38/tumblr_inline_nzet5rcFDo1spdvr2_540.png%22%3E%3Cimg%20alt=%22%22%20src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/33ab569f8d0e4e9c4613aad1aad753b4/tumblr_inline_pecnpoduG61t17fny_540.png%22%20data-orig-height=%22368%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/4bb815ba6ae9e8ca100f753effd78d38/tumblr_inline_nzet5rcFDo1spdvr2_540.png%22/%3E%3C/figure%3E%3Cp%3EStorm%200.11.0:%3C/p%3E%3Cfigure%20class=%22tmblr-full%22%20data-orig-height=%22368%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/5f611487a173ab399ed20ca7ad189bc7/tumblr_inline_nzet5oN3y51spdvr2_540.png%22%3E%3Cimg%20alt=%22%22%20src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/9255fe4023b25e55db88ace3888c2c9d/tumblr_inline_pecnppMNnm1t17fny_540.png%22%20data-orig-height=%22368%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/5f611487a173ab399ed20ca7ad189bc7/tumblr_inline_nzet5oN3y51spdvr2_540.png%22/%3E%3C/figure%3E%3Cp%3EStorm%20compared%20favorably%20to%20both%20Flink%20and%20Spark%20Streaming.%20Storm%200.11.0%20beat%20Storm%200.10.0,%20showing%20the%20optimizations%20that%20have%20gone%20in%20since%20the%200.10.0%20release.%20However,%20at%20high-throughput%20both%20versions%20of%20Storm%20struggled.%20Storm%200.10.0%20was%20not%20able%20to%20handle%20throughputs%20above%20135,000%20events%20per%20second.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EStorm%200.11.0%20performed%20similarly%20until%20we%20disabled%20acking.%20In%20the%20benchmarking%20topology,%20acking%20was%20used%20for%20flow%20control%20but%20not%20for%20processing%20guarantees.%20In%200.11.0,%20Storm%20added%20a%20simple%20back%20pressure%20controller,%20allowing%20us%20to%20avoid%20the%20overhead%20of%20acking.%20With%20acking%20enabled,%200.11.0%20performed%20terribly%20at%20150,000/s%E2%80%94slightly%20better%20than%200.10.0,%20but%20still%20far%20worse%20than%20anything%20else.%20With%20acking%20disabled,%20Storm%20even%20beat%20Flink%20for%20latency%20at%20high%20throughput.%20However,%20with%20acking%20disabled,%20the%20ability%20to%20report%20and%20handle%20tuple%20failures%20is%20disabled%20also.%3C/p%3E%3Ch2%3E%3Cb%3EConclusions%20and%20Future%20Work%3C/b%3E%3C/h2%3E%3Cp%3EIt%20is%20interesting%20to%20compare%20the%20behavior%20of%20these%20three%20systems.%20Looking%20at%20the%20following%20figure,%20we%20can%20see%20that%20Storm%20and%20Flink%20both%20respond%20quite%20linearly.%20This%20is%20because%20these%20two%20systems%20try%20to%20process%20an%20incoming%20event%20as%20it%20becomes%20available.%20On%20the%20other%20hand,%20the%20Spark%20Streaming%20system%20behaves%20in%20a%20stepwise%20function,%20a%20direct%20result%20from%20its%20micro-batching%20design.%3C/p%3E%3Cfigure%20class=%22tmblr-full%22%20data-orig-height=%22368%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/f2bfdf7856cc5b74ac0b13a2d6747f16/tumblr_inline_nzet5qLI4P1spdvr2_540.png%22%3E%3Cimg%20alt=%22%22%20src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/072bb01c8918be0ebfceadb78ecb8368/tumblr_inline_pecnpryDuG1t17fny_540.png%22%20data-orig-height=%22368%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/f2bfdf7856cc5b74ac0b13a2d6747f16/tumblr_inline_nzet5qLI4P1spdvr2_540.png%22/%3E%3C/figure%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20throughput%20vs%20latency%20graph%20for%20the%20various%20systems%20is%20maybe%20the%20most%20revealing,%20as%20it%20summarizes%20our%20findings%20with%20this%20benchmark.%20Flink%20and%20Storm%20have%20very%20similar%20performance,%20and%20Spark%20Streaming,%20while%20it%20has%20much%20higher%20latency,%20is%20expected%20to%20be%20able%20to%20handle%20much%20higher%20throughput.%3C/p%3E%3Cfigure%20class=%22tmblr-full%22%20data-orig-height=%22365%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/09114914eb9baead2d40b782742c5e72/tumblr_inline_nzet5oLKk51spdvr2_540.png%22%3E%3Cimg%20alt=%22%22%20src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/034b6bfeff359d1e12545a6a38563a25/tumblr_inline_pecnpr7Kxo1t17fny_540.png%22%20data-orig-height=%22365%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/09114914eb9baead2d40b782742c5e72/tumblr_inline_nzet5oLKk51spdvr2_540.png%22/%3E%3C/figure%3E%3Cp%3EWe%20did%20not%20include%20the%20results%20for%20Storm%200.10.0%20and%200.11.0%20with%20acking%20enabled%20beyond%20135,000%20events%20per%20second,%20because%20they%20could%20not%20keep%20up%20with%20the%20throughput.%20The%20resulting%20graph%20had%20the%20final%20point%20for%20Storm%200.10.0%20in%20the%2045,000%20ms%20range,%20dwarfing%20every%20other%20line%20on%20the%20graph.%20The%20longer%20the%20topology%20ran,%20the%20higher%20the%20latencies%20got,%20indicating%20that%20it%20was%20losing%20ground.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EAll%20of%20these%20benchmarks%20except%20where%20otherwise%20noted%20were%20performed%20using%20default%20settings%20for%20Storm,%20Spark,%20and%20Flink,%20and%20we%20focused%20on%20writing%20correct,%20easy%20to%20understand%20programs%20without%20optimizing%20each%20to%20its%20full%20potential.%20Because%20of%20this%20each%20of%20the%20six%20steps%20were%20a%20separate%20bolt%20or%20spout.%20Flink%20and%20Spark%20both%20do%20operator%20combining%20automatically,%20but%20Storm%20(without%20Trident)%20does%20not.%20What%20this%20means%20for%20Storm%20is%20that%20events%20go%20through%20many%20more%20steps%20and%20have%20a%20higher%20overhead%20compared%20to%20the%20other%20systems.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EIn%20addition%20to%20further%20optimizations%20to%20Storm,%20we%20would%20like%20to%20expand%20the%20benchmark%20in%20terms%20of%20functionality,%20and%20to%20include%20other%20stream%20processing%20systems%20like%20Samza%20and%20Apex.%20We%20would%20also%20like%20to%20ta e%20collaborative%20filtering%20algorithm%20for%20implicit%20feedback%20described%20in%20(Hu%20et.%20al.%202008).%20The%20data%20is%20said%20to%20be%20implicit%20because%20the%20users%20did%20not%20explicitly%20rate%20each%20blog%20post%20they%20have%20read.%20Instead,%20the%20have%20%E2%80%9Cliked%E2%80%9D%20blog%20posts%20they%20have%20likely%20enjoyed%20(positive%20feedback)%20but%20did%20not%20have%20the%20chance%20to%20%E2%80%9Cdislike%E2%80%9D%20blog%20posts%20they%20did%20not%20enjoy%20(absence%20of%20negative%20feedback).%20Because%20of%20that,%20implicit%20feedback%20is%20said%20to%20be%20inherently%20noisy%20and%20the%20fact%20that%20a%20user%20did%20not%20%E2%80%9Clike%E2%80%9D%20a%20blog%20post%20might%20have%20many%20different%20reasons%20not%20related%20with%20his%20negative%20feelings%20about%20that%20blog%20post.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EIn%20terms%20of%20modeling,%20a%20big%20difference%20between%20explicit%20and%20implicit%20feedback%20datasets%20is%20that%20the%20ratings%20for%20the%20explicit%20feedback%20are%20typically%20unknown%20for%20the%20majority%20of%20user-item%20pairs%20and%20are%20treated%20as%20missing%20values%20and%20ignored%20by%20the%20training%20algorithm.%20For%20an%20implicit%20dataset,%20we%20would%20assume%20a%20rating%20of%20zero%20in%20case%20the%20user%20has%20not%20liked%20a%20blog%20post.%20To%20encode%20the%20fact%20that%20a%20value%20of%20zero%20could%20come%20from%20different%20reasons%20we%20will%20use%20the%20concept%20of%20confidence%20as%20introduced%20by%20(Hu%20et.%20al.%202008),%20which%20causes%20the%20positive%20feedback%20to%20have%20a%20higher%20weight%20than%20a%20negative%20feedback.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EOnce%20we%20train%20the%20collaborative%20filtering%20model,%20we%20will%20have%20one%20vector%20representing%20a%20latent%20factor%20for%20each%20user%20and%20item%20contained%20in%20the%20training%20set.%20Those%20vectors%20will%20later%20be%20used%20in%20the%20Vespa%20ranking%20framework%20to%20make%20recommendations%20to%20a%20user%20based%20on%20the%20dot%20product%20between%20the%20user%20and%20documents%20latent%20factors.%20An%20obvious%20problem%20with%20this%20approach%20is%20that%20new%20users%20and%20new%20documents%20will%20not%20have%20those%20latent%20factors%20available%20to%20them.%20This%20is%20what%20is%20called%20a%20cold%20start%20problem%20and%20will%20be%20addressed%20with%20content-based%20techniques%20described%20in%20future%20posts.%3C/p%3E%3Ch2%3EEvaluation%20metrics%3C/h2%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20evaluation%20metric%20used%20by%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://www.kaggle.com/c/predict-wordpress-likes/details/evaluation%22%3EKaggle%3C/a%3E%20for%20this%20challenge%20was%20the%20Mean%20Average%20Precision%20at%20100%20(MAP@100).%20However,%20since%20we%20do%20not%20have%20information%20about%20which%20blog%20posts%20the%20users%20did%20not%20like%20(that%20is,%20we%20have%20only%20positive%20feedback)%20and%20our%20inability%20to%20obtain%20user%20behavior%20to%20the%20recommendations%20we%20make%20(this%20is%20an%20offline%20evaluation,%20different%20from%20the%20usual%20A/B%20testing%20performed%20by%20companies%20that%20use%20recommendation%20systems),%20we%20offer%20a%20similar%20remark%20as%20the%20one%20included%20in%20(Hu%20et.%20al.%202008)%20and%20prefer%20recall-oriented%20measures.%20Following%20(Hu%20et.%20al.%202008)%20we%20will%20use%20the%20expected%20percentile%20ranking.%3C/p%3E%3Ch2%3EEvaluation%20Framework%3C/h2%3E%3Cp%3E%3Cb%3EGenerate%20training%20and%20test%20sets%3C/b%3E%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EIn%20order%20to%20evaluate%20the%20gains%20obtained%20by%20the%20recommendation%20system%20when%20we%20start%20to%20improve%20it%20with%20more%20accurate%20algorithms,%20we%20will%20split%20the%20dataset%20we%20have%20available%20into%20training%20and%20test%20sets.%20The%20training%20set%20will%20contain%20document%20(blog%20post)%20and%20user%20action%20(likes)%20pairs%20as%20well%20as%20any%20information%20available%20about%20the%20documents%20contained%20in%20the%20training%20set.%20There%20is%20no%20additional%20information%20about%20the%20users%20besides%20the%20blog%20posts%20they%20have%20liked.%20The%20test%20set%20will%20be%20formed%20by%20a%20series%20of%20documents%20available%20to%20be%20recommended%20and%20a%20set%20of%20users%20to%20whom%20we%20need%20to%20make%20recommendations.%20This%20list%20of%20test%20set%20documents%20constitutes%20the%20Vespa%20content%20pool,%20which%20is%20the%20set%20of%20documents%20stored%20in%20Vespa%20that%20are%20available%20to%20be%20served%20to%20users.%20The%20user%20actions%20will%20be%20hidden%20from%20the%20test%20set%20and%20used%20later%20to%20evaluate%20the%20recommendations%20made%20by%20Vespa.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3ETo%20create%20an%20application%20that%20more%20closely%20resembles%20the%20challenges%20faced%20by%20companies%20when%20building%20their%20recommendation%20systems,%20we%20decided%20to%20construct%20the%20training%20and%20test%20sets%20in%20such%20a%20way%20that:%3C/p%3E%3Cul%3E%3Cli%3EThere%20will%20be%20blog%20posts%20that%20had%20been%20liked%20in%20the%20training%20set%20by%20a%20set%20of%20users%20and%20that%20had%20also%20been%20liked%20in%20the%20test%20set%20by%20another%20set%20of%20users,%20even%20though%20this%20information%20will%20be%20hidden%20in%20the%20test%20set.%20Those%20cases%20are%20interesting%20to%20evaluate%20if%20the%20exploitation%20(as%20opposed%20to%20exploration)%20component%20of%20the%20system%20is%20working%20well.%20That%20is,%20if%20we%20are%20able%20to%20identify%20high%20quality%20blog%20posts%20based%20on%20the%20available%20information%20during%20training%20and%20exploit%20this%20knowledge%20by%20recommending%20those%20high%20quality%20blog%20posts%20to%20another%20set%20of%20users%20that%20might%20like%20them%20as%20well.%3C/li%3E%3Cli%3EThere%20will%20be%20blog%20posts%20in%20the%20test%20set%20that%20had%20never%20been%20seen%20in%20the%20training%20set.%20Those%20cases%20are%20interesting%20in%20order%20to%20evaluate%20how%20the%20system%20deals%20with%20the%20cold-start%20problem.%20Systems%20that%20are%20too%20biased%20towards%20exploitation%20will%20fail%20to%20recommend%20new%20and%20unexplored%20blog%20posts,%20leading%20to%20a%20feedback%20loop%20that%20will%20cause%20the%20system%20to%20focus%20into%20a%20small%20share%20of%20the%20available%20content.%3C/li%3E%3C/ul%3E%3Cp%3EA%20key%20challenge%20faced%20by%20recommender%20system%20designers%20is%20how%20to%20balance%20the%20exploitation/exploration%20components%20of%20their%20system,%20and%20our%20training/test%20set%20split%20outlined%20above%20will%20try%20to%20replicate%20this%20challenge%20in%20our%20application.%20Notice%20that%20this%20split%20is%20different%20from%20the%20approach%20taken%20by%20the%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://www.kaggle.com/c/predict-wordpress-likes%22%3EKaggle%20competition%3C/a%3E%20where%20the%20blog%20posts%20available%20in%20the%20test%20set%20had%20never%20been%20seen%20in%20the%20training%20set,%20which%20removes%20the%20exploitation%20component%20of%20the%20equation.%3Cbr/%3E%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20Spark%20job%20uses%20%3Ccode%3EtrainPosts.json%3C/code%3E%20and%20creates%20the%20folders%20%3Ccode%3Eblog-job/training_set_ids%3C/code%3E%20and%20%3Ccode%3Eblog-job/test_set_ids%3C/code%3E%20containing%20files%20with%20%3Ccode%3Epost_id%3C/code%3E%20and%20%3Ccode%3Euser_id%3C/code%3Epairs:%3C/p%3E%3Cpre%3E%3Ccode%3E$%20cd%20blog-recommendation;%20export%20SPARK_LOCAL_IP=%22127.0.0.1%22$%20spark-submit%20--class%20%22com.yahoo.example.blog.BlogRecommendationApp%22%20\%20%C2%A0--master%20local[4]%20../blog-tutorial-shared/target/scala-*/blog-support*.jar%20\%20%C2%A0--task%20split_set%20--input_file%20../trainPosts.json%20\%20%C2%A0--test_perc_stage1%200.05%20--test_perc_stage2%200.20%20--seed%20123%20\%20%C2%A0--output_path%20blog-job/training_and_test_indices%3C/code%3E%3C/pre%3E%3Cul%3E%3Cli%3Etest_perc_stage1:%20The%20percentage%20of%20the%20blog%20posts%20that%20will%20be%20located%20only%20on%20the%20test%20s king%20expressions%20of%20such%20complexity%20at%20scale.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EVespa%20comes%20with%20a%20Tensor%20framework,%20which%20unify%20and%20generalizes%20scalar,%20vector%20and%20matrix%20operations,%20handles%20the%20sparseness%20inherent%20to%20most%20machine%20learning%20application%20(most%20cases%20evaluated%20by%20the%20model%20is%20lacking%20values%20for%20most%20of%20the%20features)%20and%20allow%20for%20models%20to%20be%20continuously%20updated.%20Additional%20information%20about%20the%20Tensor%20framework%20can%20be%20found%20in%20the%20%3Ca%20href=%22http://docs.vespa.ai/documentation/tensor-user-guide.html%22%3Etensor%20user%20guide%3C/a%3E.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EWe%20want%20to%20have%20those%20latent%20factors%20available%20in%20a%20Tensor%20representation%20to%20be%20used%20during%20ranking%20by%20the%20Tensor%20framework.%20A%20tensor%20field%20%3Ccode%3Euser_item_cf%3C/code%3E%20is%20added%20to%20%3Ccode%3Eblog_post.sd%3C/code%3E%20to%20hold%20the%20blog%20post%20latent%20factor:%3C/p%3E%3Cpre%3E%3Ccode%3Efield%20user_item_cf%20type%20tensor(user_item_cf[10])%20{indexing:%20summary%20|%20attributeattribute:%20tensor(user_item_cf[10])}field%20has_user_item_cf%20type%20byte%20{indexing:%20summary%20|%20attributeattribute:%20fast-search}%3C/code%3E%3C/pre%3E%3Cp%3EA%20new%20search%20definition%20%3Ccode%3Euser.sd%3C/code%3E%20defines%20a%20document%20type%20named%20%3Ccode%3Euser%3C/code%3E%20to%20hold%20information%20for%20users:%3C/p%3E%3Cpre%3E%3Ccode%3Esearch%20user%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0document%20user%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0field%20user_id%20type%20string%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0indexing:%20summary%20|%20attribute%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0attribute:%20fast-search%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0field%20has_read_items%20type%20array&lt;string&gt;%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0indexing:%20summary%20|%20attribute%2 2http://localhost:8080/search/?yql=select%20*%20from%20sources%20blog_post%20where%20has_user_item_cf%20=%201;&amp;ranking=tensor&amp;ranking.features.query(user_item_cf)=%7B%7Buser_item_cf%3A0%7D%3A0.1%2C%7Buser_item_cf%3A1%7D%3A0.1%2C%7Buser_item_cf%3A2%7D%3A0.1%2C%7Buser_item_cf%3A3%7D%3A0.1%2C%7Buser_item_cf%3A4%7D%3A0.1%2C%7Buser_item_cf%3A5%7D%3A0.1%2C%7Buser_item_cf%3A6%7D%3A0.1%2C%7Buser_item_cf%3A7%7D%3A0.1%2C%7Buser_item_cf%3A8%7D%3A0.1%2C%7Buser_item_cf%3A9%7D%3A0.1%7D%22%3Elocalhost:8080/search/?yql=select%20*%20from%20sources%20blog_post%20where%20has_user_item_cf%20=%201;&amp;ranking=tensor&amp;ranking.features.query(user_item_cf)=%7B%7Buser_item_cf%3A0%7D%3A0.1%2C%7Buser_item_cf%3A1%7D%3A0.1%2C%7Buser_item_cf%3A2%7D%3A0.1%2C%7Buser_item_cf%3A3%7D%3A0.1%2C%7Buser_item_cf%3A4%7D%3A0.1%2C%7Buser_item_cf%3A5%7D%3A0.1%2C%7Buser_item_cf%3A6%7D%3A0.1%2C%7Buser_item_cf%3A7%7D%3A0.1%2C%7Buser_item_cf%3A8%7D%3A0.1%2C%7Buser_item_cf%3A9%7D%3A0.1%7D%3C/a%3E%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20query%20string,%20decomposed:%3C/p%3E%3Cul%3E%3Cli%3Eyql=select%20*%20from%20sources%20blog_post%20where%20has_user_item_cf%20=%201%20-%20this%20selects%20all%20documents%20of%20type%20blog_post%20which%20has%20a%20latent%20factor%20tensor%3C/li%3E%3Cli%3Erestrict=blog_post%20-%20search%20only%20in%20%3Ccode%3Eblog_post%3C/code%3E%20documents%3C/li%3E%3Cli%3Eranking=tensor%20-%20use%20the%20rank-profile%20%3Ccode%3Etensor%3C/code%3E%20in%20%3Ccode%3Eblog_post.sd%3C/code%3E.%3C/li%3E%3Cli%3Eranking.features.query(user_item_cf)%20-%20send%20the%20tensor%20as%20user_item_cf.%20As%20this%20tensor%20is%20defined%20in%20the%20query-profile-type,%20the%20ranking%20framework%20knows%20its%20type%20(i.e.%20dimensions)%20and%20is%20able%20to%20do%20a%20dot%20product%20with%20the%20attribute%20of%20same%20type.%20The%20tensor%20before%20URL-encoding:%3C/li%3E%3C/ul%3E%3Cpre%3E%3Ccode%3E{%20%C2%A0{user_item_cf:0}:0.1,%20%C2%A0{user_item_cf:1}:0.1,%20%C2%A0{user_item_cf:2}:0.1,%20%C2%A0{user_item_cf:3}:0.1,%20%C2%A0{user_item_cf:4}:0.1,%20%C2%A0{user_item_cf:5}:0.1,%20%C2%A0{user_item_cf:6}:0.1,%20%C2%A0{user_item_cf:7}:0.1,%20%C2%A0{user_item_cf:8}:0.1,%20%C2%A0{user_item_cf:9}:0.1}%3C/code%3E%3C/pre%3E%3Ch2%3EQuery%20Vespa%20with%20user%20id%3C/h2%3E%3Cp%3ENext%20step%20is%20to%20query%20Vespa%20by%20user%20id,%20look%20up%20the%20user%20profile%20for%20the%20user,%20get%20the%20tensor%20from%20it%20and%20recommend%20documents%20based%20on%20this%20tensor%20(like%20the%20query%20in%20previous%20section).%20The%20user%20profiles%20is%20fed%20to%20Vespa%20in%20the%20%3Ccode%3Euser_item_cf%3C/code%3E%20field%20of%20the%20%3Ccode%3Euser%3C/code%3E%20document%20type.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EIn%20short,%20set%20up%20a%20%3Ca%20href=%22http://docs.vespa.ai/documentation/searcher-development.html%22%3Esearcher%3C/a%3E%20to%20retrieve%20the%20user%20profile%20by%20user%20id%20-%20then%20run%20the%20query.%20When%20the%20%3Ca%20href=%22http://docs.vespa.ai/documentation/container-intro.html%22%3EVespa%20Container%3C/a%3E%20receives%20a%20request,%20it%20will%20create%20a%20%3Ccode%3EQuery%3C/code%3E%20representing%20it%20and%20execute%20a%20configured%20list%20of%20such%20Searcher%20components,%20called%20a%20%3Ca%20href=%22http://docs.vespa.ai/documentation/chained-components.html%22%3Esearch%20chain%3C/a%3E.%20The%20%3Ccode%3Equery%3C/code%3E%20object%20contains%20all%20the%20information%20needed%20to%20create%20a%20result%20to%20the%20request%20while%20the%20%3Ccode%3EResult%3C/code%3E%20encapsulates%20all%20the%20data%20generated%20from%20a%20%3Ccode%3EQuery%3C/code%3E.%20The%20%3Ccode%3EExecution%3C/code%3E%20object%20keeps%20track%20of%20the%20call%20state%20for%20an%20execution%20of%20the%20searchers%20of%20a%20search%20chain:%3C/p%3E%3Cpre%3E%3Ccode%3Epackage%20com.yahoo.example;import%20com.yahoo.data.access.Inspectable;import%20com.yahoo.data.access.Inspector;import%20com.yahoo.prelude.query.IntItem;import%20com.yahoo.prelude.query.NotItem;import%20com.yahoo.prelude.query.WordItem;import%20com.yahoo.processing.request.CompoundName;import%20com.yahoo.search.Query;import%20com.yahoo.search.Result;import%20com.yahoo.search.Searcher;import%20com.yahoo.search.querytransform.QueryTreeUtil;import%20com.yahoo.search.result.Hit;import%20com.yahoo.search.searchchain.Execution;import%20com.yahoo.search.searchchain.SearchChain;import%20com.yahoo.tensor.Tensor;import%20java.util.ArrayList;import%20java.util.Iterator;import%20java.util.List;public%20class%20UserProfileSearcher%20extends%20Searcher%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0public%20Result%20search(Query%20query,%20Execution%20execution)%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0//%20Get%20tensor%20and%20read%20items%20from%20user%20profile%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0Object%20userIdProperty%20=%20query.properties().get(%22user_id%22);%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0if%20(userIdProperty%20!=%20null)%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0Hit%20userProfile%20=%20retrieveUserProfile(userIdProperty.toString(),%20execution);%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0if%20(userProfile%20!=%20null)%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0addUserProfileTensorToQuery(query,%20userProfile);%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0NotItem%20notItem%20=%20new%20NotItem();%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0notItem.addItem(new%20IntItem(1,%20%22has_user_item_cf%22));%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0for%20(String%20item%20:%20getReadItems(userProfile.getField(%22has_read_items%22))){%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0notItem.addItem(new%20WordItem(item,%20%22post_id%22));%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0QueryTreeUtil.andQueryItemWithRoot(query,%20notItem);%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0//%20Restric%20to%20search%20in%20blog_posts%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0query.getModel().setRestrict(%22blog_post%22);%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0//%20Rank%20blog%20posts%20using%20tensor%20rank%20profile%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0if(query.properties().get(%22ranking%22)%20==%20null)%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0query.properties().set(new%20CompoundName(%22ranking%22),%20%22tensor%22);%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0return%20execution.search(query);%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0private%20Hit%20retrieveUserProfile(String%20userId,%20Execution%20execution)%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0Query%20query%20=%20new%20Query();%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0query.getModel().setRestrict(%22user%22);%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0query.getModel().getQueryTree().setRoot(new%20WordItem(userId,%20%22user_id%22));%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0query.setHits(1);%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0SearchChain%20vespaChain%20=%20execution.searchChainRegistry().getComponent(%22vespa%22);%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0Result%20result%20=%20new%20Execution(vespaChain,%20execution.context()).search(query);%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0execution.fill(result);%20//%20This%20is%20needed%20to%20get%20the%20actual%20summary%20data%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0Iterator&lt;Hit&gt;%20hiterator%20=%20result.hits().deepIterator();%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0return%20hiterator.hasNext()%20?%20hiterator.next()%20:%20null;%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0private%20void%20addUserProfileTensorToQuery(Query%20query,%20Hit%20userProfile)%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0Object%20userItemCf%20=%20userProfile.getField(%22user_item_cf%22);%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0if%20(userItemCf%20!=%20null)%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20% ql=select%20*%20from%20sources%20blog_post%20where%20content%20contains%20%22pegasus%22;%22%3Elocalhost:8080/search/?user_id=34030991&amp;searchChain=user&amp;yql=select%20*%20from%20sources%20blog_post%20where%20content%20contains%20%22pegasus%22;%3C/a%3E%3C/p%3E%3Ch2%3EModel%20tuning%20and%20offline%20evaluation%3C/h2%3E%3Cp%3EWe%20will%20now%20optimize%20the%20latent%20factors%20using%20the%20training%20set%20instead%20of%20manually%20picking%20hyperparameter%20values%20as%20was%20done%20in%20Compute%20user%20and%20item%20latent%20factors:%3C/p%3E%3Cpre%3E%3Ccode%3E$%20spark-submit%20--class%20%22com.yahoo.example.blog.BlogRecommendationApp%22%20\%20%C2%A0--master%20local[4]%20../blog-tutorial-shared/target/scala-*/blog-support*.jar%20\%20%C2%A0--task%20collaborative_filtering_cv%20\%20%C2%A0--input_file%20blog-job/training_and_test_indices/training_set_ids%20\%20%C2%A0--numIterations%2010%20--output_path%20blog-job/user_item_cf_cv%3C/code%3E%3C/pre%3E%3Cp%3EFeed%20the%20newly%20computed%20latent%20factors%20to%20Vespa%20as%20before.%20Note%20that%20we%20need%20to%20update%20the%20tensor%20specification%20in%20the%20search%20definition%20in%20case%20the%20size%20of%20the%20latent%20vectors%20change.%20We%20have%20used%20size%2010%20(rank%20=%2010)%20in%20the%20Compute%20user%20and%20item%20latent%20factors%20section%20but%20our%20cross-validation%20algorithm%20above%20tries%20different%20values%20for%20rank%20(10,%2050,%20100).%3C/p%3E%3Cpre%3E%3Ccode%3E$%20pig%20-Dvespa.feed.defaultport=8080%20-Dvespa.feed.random.startup.sleep.ms=0%20\%20%C2%A0-x%20local%20\%20%C2%A0-f%20../blog-tutorial-shared/src/main/pig/tutorial_feed_content_and_tensor_vespa.pig%20\%20%C2%A0-param%20VESPA_HADOOP_JAR=../vespa-hadoop*.jar%20\%20%C2%A0-param%20DATA_PATH=../trainPosts.json%20\%20%C2%A0-param%20TEST_INDICES=blog-job/training_and_test_indices/testing_set_ids%20\%20%C2%A0-param%20BLOG_POST_FACTORS=blog-job/user_item_cf_cv/product_features%20\%20%C2%A0-param%20USER_FACTORS=blog-job/ 0was%20approximately%205Gb.%20Data%20sets%20of%20this%20size%20do%20not%20require%20a%20distributed%20file%20system%20for%20data%20manipulation.%20However,%20we%20assume%20that%20most%20Vespa%20users%20would%20like%20at%20some%20point%20to%20scale%20their%20applications%20up.%20Therefore,%20this%20tutorial%20uses%20tools%20such%20as%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://hadoop.apache.org/%22%3EApache%20Hadoop%3C/a%3E,%C2%A0%3Ca%20href=%22https://pig.apache.org/%22%3EApache%20Pig%3C/a%3E%20and%20%3Ca%20href=%22http://spark.apache.org/%22%3EApache%20Spark%3C/a%3E.%20These%20can%20be%20run%20locally%20on%20a%20laptop,%20like%20in%20this%20tutorial.%20In%20case%20you%20would%20like%20to%20use%20HDFS%20(Hadoop%20Distributed%20File%20System)%20for%20storing%20the%20data,%20it%20is%20just%20a%20matter%20of%20uploading%20it%20to%20HDFS%20with%20the%20following%20command:%3C/p%3E%3Cpre%3E%3Ccode%3E$%20hadoop%20fs%20-put%20trainPosts.json%20blog-app/trainPosts.json%3C/code%3E%3C/pre%3E%3Cp%3EIf%20you%20go%20with%20this%20approach,%20you%20need%20to%20replace%20the%20local%20file%20paths%20with%20the%20equivalent%20HDFS%20file%20paths%20in%20this%20tutorial.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EVespa%20has%20%3Ca%20href=%22http://docs.vespa.ai/documentation/feed-using-hadoop-pig-oozie.html%22%3Ea%20set%20of%20tools%3C/a%3E%20to%20facilitate%20the%20interaction%20between%20Vespa%20and%20the%20Hadoop%20ecosystem.%20These%20can%20also%20be%20used%20locally.%20A%20Pig%20script%20example%20of%20feeding%20to%20Vespa%20is%20as%20simple%20as:%3C/p%3E%3Cpre%3E%3Ccode%3EREGISTER%20vespa-hadoop.jarDEFINE%20VespaStorage%20com.yahoo.vespa.hadoop.pig.VespaStorage();A%20=%20LOAD%20'&lt;path&gt;'%20[USING%20&lt;storage&gt;]%20[AS%20&lt;schema&gt;];--%20apply%20any%20transformationsSTORE%20A%20INTO%20'$ENDPOINT'%20USING%20VespaStorage();%3C/code%3E%3C/pre%3E%3Cp%3EUse%20Pig%20to%20feed%20a%20file%20into%20Vespa:%3C/p%3E%3Cpre%3E%3Ccode%3E$%20pig%20-x%20local%20-f%20feed.pig%20-p%20ENDPOINT=endpoint-1,endpoint-2%3C/code%3E%3C/pre%3E%3Cp%3EHere,%20the%20-x%20local%20option%20is%20added%20to%20specify%20that%20this%20script%20is%20run%20locally,%20and%20will%20not%20attempt%20to%20retrieve%20scripts%20and%20data%20from%20HDFS.%20You%20need%20both%20Pig%20and%20Hadoop%20libraries%20installed%20on%20your%20machine%20to%20run%20this%20locally,%20but%20you%20don%E2%80%99t%20need%20to%20install%20and%20start%20a%20running%20instance%20of%20Hadoop.%20More%20examples%20of%20feeding%20to%20Vespa%20from%20Pig%20is%20found%20in%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://github.com/vespa-engine/sample-apps/tree/master/blog-tutorial-shared/src/main/pig%22%3Esample%20apps%3C/a%3E.%3C/p%3E,http://blog.vespa.ai/post/168083726636
mailto:?subject=Blog%20recommendation%20with%20neural%20network%20models&body=%3Ch2%3EIntroduction%3C/h2%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20main%20objective%20of%20this%20post%20is%20to%20show%20how%20to%20deploy%20neural%20network%20models%20in%20Vespa%20using%20our%20Tensor%20Framework.%20In%20fact,%20any%20model%20that%20can%20be%20represented%20by%20a%20series%20of%20Tensor%20operations%20can%20be%20deployed%20in%20Vespa.%20Neural%20networks%20is%20just%20a%20popular%20example.%20In%20addition,%20we%20will%20introduce%20the%20multi-phase%20ranking%20model%20available%20in%20Vespa%20that%20can%20be%20used%20to%20run%20more%20expensive%20models%20in%20a%20phase%20based%20on%20a%20reduced%20number%20of%20documents%20returned%20by%20previous%20phases.%20This%20feature%20allow%20us%20to%20run%20models%20that%20would%20be%20prohibitively%20expensive%20to%20use%20if%20we%20had%20to%20run%20them%20at%20query-time%20across%20all%20the%20documents%20indexed%20in%20Vespa.%3C/p%3E%3Ch2%3EModel%20Training%3C/h2%3E%3Cp%3EIn%20this%20section,%20we%20will%20define%20a%20neural%20network%20model,%20show%20how%20we%20created%20a%20suitable%20dataset%20to%20train%20the%20model%20and%20train%20the%20model%20using%20TensorFlow.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3E%3Cb%3EThe%20neural%20network%20model%3C/b%3E%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EIn%20the%20previous%20blog%20post,%20we%20computed%20latent%20factors%20for%20each%20user%20and%20each%20document%20and%20then%20used%20a%20dot-product%20between%20user%20and%20document%20vectors%20to%20rank%20the%20documents%20available%20for%20recommendation%20to%20a%20specific%20user.%20In%20this%20tutorial%20we%20will%20train%20a%202-layer%20fully%20connected%20neural%20network%20model%20that%20will%20take%20the%20same%20user%20(%3Ci%3Eu%3C/i%3E)%20and%20document%20(%3Ci%3Ed%3C/i%3E)%20latent%20factors%20as%20input%20and%20will%20output%20the%20probability%20of%20that%20specific%20user%20liking%20the%20document.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EMore%20technically,%20our%20previous%20rank%20function%20%3Ci%3Er%3C/i%3E%20w 0will%20scan%20all%20documents%20available%20and%20select%20the%20ones%20(possibly%20all)%20that%20match%20the%20query.%20When%20the%20set%20of%20documents%20matching%20a%20query%20is%20found,%20Vespa%20must%20decide%20the%20order%20of%20these%20documents.%20Unless%20explicit%20sorting%20is%20used,%20Vespa%20decides%20this%20order%20by%20calculating%20a%20number%20for%20each%20document,%20the%20rank%20score,%20and%20sorts%20the%20documents%20by%20this%20number.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20rank%20score%20can%20be%20any%20function%20that%20takes%20as%20arguments%20parameters%20sent%20by%20the%20query,%20document%20attributes%20defined%20in%20search%20definitions%20and%20global%20parameters%20not%20directly%20linked%20to%20query%20or%20document%20parameters.%20One%20example%20of%20rank%20score%20is%20the%20output%20of%20the%20neural%20network%20model%20defined%20in%20this%20tutorial.%20The%20model%20takes%20the%20latent%20factor%20%3Ci%3Eu%3C/i%3E%20associated%20with%20a%20specific%20%3Ccode%3Euser_id%3C/code%3E%20(query%20parameter),%20the%20latent%20factor%20dd%20associated%20with%20document%20%3Ccode%3Epost_id%3C/code%3E%20(document%20attribute)%20and%20learned%20model%20parameters%20(global%20parameters%20not%20related%20to%20a%20specific%20query%20nor%20document)%20and%20returns%20the%20probability%20of%20user%20%3Ci%3Eu%3C/i%3E%20to%20like%20document%20%3Ci%3Ed%3C/i%3E.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EHowever,%20even%20though%20Vespa%20is%20designed%20to%20carry%20out%20such%20calculations%20optimally,%20complex%20expressions%20becomes%20expensive%20when%20they%20must%20be%20calculated%20over%20every%20one%20of%20a%20large%20set%20of%20matching%20documents.%20To%20relieve%20this,%20Vespa%20can%20be%20configured%20to%20run%20two%20ranking%20expressions%20-%20a%20smaller%20and%20less%20accurate%20one%20on%20all%20hits%20during%20the%20matching%20phase,%20and%20a%20more%20expensive%20and%20accurate%20one%20only%20on%20the%20best%20hits%20during%20the%20reranking%20phase.%20In%20general%20this%20allows%20a%20more%20optimal%20usage%20of%20the%20cpu%20budget%20by%20dedicating%20more%20of%20the%20total%20cpu%20towards%20the%20best%20candidate%20hits.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20reranking%20phase,%20if%20specified,%20will%20by%20default%20be%20run%20on%20the%20100%20best%20hits%20on%20each%20search%20node,%20after%20matching%20and%20before%20information%20is%20returned%20upwards%20to%20the%20search%20container.%20The%20number%20of%20hits%20to%20rerank%20can%20be%20turned%20up%20or%20down%20as%20needed.%20Below%20is%20a%20toy%20example%20showing%20how%20to%20configure%20first%20and%20second%20phase%20ranking%20expressions%20in%20the%20rank%20profile%20section%20of%20search%20definitions%20where%20the%20second%20phase%20rank%20expression%20is%20run%20on%20the%20200%20best%20hits%20from%20first%20phase%20on%20each%20search%20node.%3C/p%3E%3Cpre%3E%3Ccode%3Esearch%20myapp%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%E2%80%A6%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0rank-profile%20default%20inherits%20default%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0first-phase%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0expression:%20nativeRank%20+%20query(deservesFreshness)%20*%20freshness(timestamp)%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0second-phase%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0expression%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A00.7%20*%20(%200.7*fieldMatch(title)%20+%200.2*fieldMatch(description)%20+%200.1*fieldMatch(body)%20)%20+%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A00.3%20*%20attributeMatch(keywords)%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0rerank-count:%20200%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}}%3C/code%3E%3C/pre%3E%3Cp%3E%3Cb%3EConstant%20Tensor%20files%3C/b%3E%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EOnce%20the%20model%20has%20been%20trained%20in%20TensorFlow,%20export%20the%20model%20parameters%20%3Ci%3E(W1,W2,b1,b2)%3C/i%3E%20to%20the%20application%20folder%20as%20Tensors%20according%20to%20the%20%3Ca%20href=%22http://docs.vespa.ai/documentation/reference/document-json-format.html%22%3EVespa%20Document%20JSON%20format%3C/a%3E.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20complete%20code%20to%20serialize%20the%20model%20parameters%20using%20Vespa%20Tensor%20format%20can%20be%20found%20in%20the%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://github.com/vespa-engine/sample-apps/tree/master/blog-tutorial-shared#export-model-parameters-to-tensor-vespa-format%22%3Eutility%20scripts%3C/a%3E%20but%20the%20following%20code%20snipped%20shows%20how%20to%20serialize%20the%20hidden%20layer%20weights%20%3Ci%3EW1%3C/i%3E:%3C/p%3E%3Cpre%3E%3Ccode%3Eserializer.serialize_to_disk(variable_name%20=%20%22W_hidden%22,%20dimension_names%20=%20['input',%20'hidden'])%3C/code%3E%3C/pre%3E%3Cp%3ENote%20that%20Vespa%20currently%20requires%20dimension%20names%20for%20all%20the%20Tensor%20dimensions%20(in%20this%20case%20%3Ci%3EW1%3C/i%3E%20is%20a%20matrix,%20therefore%20dimension%20is%202).%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EIn%20the%20following%20section,%20we%20will%20use%20the%20following%20code%20in%20the%20%3Ccode%3Eblog_post%3C/code%3E%20search%20definition%20in%20order%20to%20be%20able%20to%20use%20the%20constant%20tensor%20%3Ccode%3EW_hidden%3C/code%3E%20in%20our%20ranking%20expression.%3C/p%3E%3Cpre%3E%3Ccode%3E%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0constant%20W_hidden%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0file:%20constants/W_hidden.json%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0type:%20tensor(input[20],hidden[40])%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%3C/code%3E%3C/pre%3E%3Cp%3EA%20constant%20tensor%20is%20data%20that%20is%20not%20specific%20to%20a%20given%20document%20type.%20In%20the%20case%20above%20we%20define%20%3Ccode%3EW_hidden%3C/code%3E%20to%20be%20a%20tensor%20with%20two%20dimensions%20(matrix),%20where%20the%20first%20dimension%20is%20named%20input%20and%20has%20size%2020%20and%20second%20dimension%20is%20named%20hidden%20and%20has%20size%2040.%20The%20data%20were%20serialized%20to%20a%20JSON%20file%20locat %20neural%20network%20model%20we%20have%20trained,%20we%20need%20to%20define%20where%20to%20find%20the%20model%20parameters%20%3Ci%3E(W1,W2,b1,b2)%3C/i%3E.%20See%20the%20previous%20section%20for%20how%20to%20write%20the%20TensorFlow%20model%20parameters%20to%20Vespa%20Tensor%20format.%3C/p%3E%3Cpre%3E%3Ccode%3E%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0#%20We%20need%20to%20specify%20the%20type%20and%20the%20location%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0#%20of%20the%20files%20storing%20tensor%20values%20for%20each%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0#%20Variable%20in%20our%20TensorFlow%20model.%20In%20this%20case,%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0#%20W_hidden,%20b_hidden,%20W_final,%20b_final%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0constant%20W_hidden%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0file:%20constants/W_hidden.json%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0type:%20tensor(input[20],hidden[40])%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0constant%20b_hidden%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0file:%20constants/b_hidden.json%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0type:%20tensor(hidden[40])%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0constant%20W_final%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0file:%20constants/W_final.json%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0type:%20tensor(hidden[40],%20final[1])%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0constant%20b_final%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0file:%20constants/b_final.json%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0type:%20tensor(final[1])%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%3C/code%3E%3C/pre%3E%3Cp%3ENow,%20we%20specify%20a%20second%20rank-profile%20called%20%3Ccode%3Enn_tensor%3C/code%3E%20that%20will%20use%20the%20same%20first%20phase%20as%20the%20rank-profile%20%3Ccode%3Etensor%3C/code%3E%20but%20will%20rerank%20the%20top%20200%20documents%20using%20the%20neural%20network%20model%20as%20second%20phase.%20We%20refer%20to%20the%20%3Ca%20href=%22http://docs.vespa.ai/documentation/reference/tensor.html%22%3ETensor%20Reference%20document%3C/a%3E%20for%20more%20information%20regarding%20the%20Tensor%20operations%20used%20in%20the%20code%20below.%3C/p%3E%3Cpre%3E%3Ccode%3E% let%20worked%20on%20any%20data%20source%20located%20in%20any%20persistence%20layer,%20you%20still%20had%20to%20implement%20an%20interface%20to%20connect%20your%20data%20source%20to%20the%20Backend%20and%20convert%20it%20into%20a%20record%20container%20format%20that%20Bullet%20understands.%20For%20instance,%20your%20data%20might%20be%20located%20in%20Kafka%20and%20be%20in%20the%20Avro%20format.%20If%20you%20were%20using%20Bullet%20on%20Storm,%20you%20would%20perhaps%20write%20a%20Storm%20Spout%20to%20read%20from%20Kafka,%20deserialize,%20and%20convert%20the%20Avro%20data%20into%20the%20Bullet%20record%20format.%20This%20was%20the%20only%20interface%20in%20Bullet%20that%20required%20our%20customers%20to%20write%20their%20own%20code.%20Not%20anymore!%20Bullet%20DSL%20is%20a%20text/configuration-based%20format%20for%20users%20to%20plug%20in%20their%20data%20to%20the%20Bullet%20Backend%20without%20having%20to%20write%20a%20single%20line%20of%20code.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3E%3Ca%20href=%22https://bullet-db.github.io/backend/dsl/%22%3EBullet%20DSL%3C/a%3E%20abstracts%20away%20the%20two%20major%20components%20for%20plugging%20data%20into%20the%20Bullet%20Backend.%20A%20Connector%20piece%20to%20read%20from%20arbitrary%20data-sources%20and%20a%20Converter%20piece%20to%20convert%20that%20read%20data%20into%20the%20Bullet%20record%20container.%20We%20currently%20support%20and%20maintain%20a%20few%20of%20these%20-%20Kafka%20and%20Pulsar%20for%20Connectors%20and%C2%A0Avro,%20Maps%20and%20arbitrary%20Java%20POJOs%20for%20Converters.%20The%20Converters%20understand%20typed%20data%20and%20can%20even%20do%20a%20bit%20of%20minor%20ETL%20(Extract,%20Transform%20and%20Load)%20if%20you%20need%20to%20change%20your%20data%20around%20before%20feeding%20it%20into%20Bullet.%20As%20always,%20the%20DSL%20components%20are%20pluggable%20and%20you%20can%20write%20your%20own%20(and%20contribute%20it%20back!)%20if%20you%20need%20one%20that%20we%20don%E2%80%99t%20support.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EWe%20appreciate%20your%2
